Parameters.Text:
There is no one right way to use Hoos Think Calmly. Whether you’ve been diagnosed with an anxiety disorder or just want some help managing everyday stress, Hoos Think Calmly is meant to be a helpful tool that’s right at your fingertips.

Hoos Think Calmly can be used alongside other treatments–such as therapy or medication–as a program to both practice concepts that you’ve already learned and add additional tools to your toolbox. If you’ve had experience with mental health treatment in the past, Hoos Think Calmly can help you maintain what you gained from treatment, hopefully making the return of anxiety symptoms less likely, and even help you make more progress!

If you have not had experience with treatment in the past, we are so happy that you are here! The skills taught in Hoos Think Calmly overlap with skills emphasized in evidence-based treatments for anxiety. Hoos Think Calmly can be an important step in managing anxiety in a free and accessible way right from your smartphone.

Hoos Think Calmly really emphasizes flexible thinking. This is one way of managing anxiety and stress, and there are many other tools out there to help you as well! If you are interested in additional tools for managing stress and anxiety, please visit the Resources tab on the main page of the app.

In whatever way you plan to use the app, we hope that the tools you learn here help you in your day-to-day life!

P1: We’d love to check in now that you’ve been able to complete a few training stories. Were you able to fully imagine yourself in the different situations?

P2: That was tricky at first but then I tried to really slow down and use my senses - thinking about what I would see and hear and feel if the story ended in the way it did once I filled in the missing letters. It was new for me because I was often expecting the stories to end worse than they actually did. It was interesting to think about different ways that situations can turn out.

P1: Great! Our program is meant to help you practice new ways of thinking, to approach situations with more flexibility and less catastrophic thinking. What are some questions that you had while using our app or thinking about each situation?

P2: Why does the text appear slowly, versus all at once?

P1: The text is appearing at the average rate of reading to help further immerse you into the story, almost as if you are watching the story unfold. Using your imagination fully takes time but the more you can vividly imagine the story, the more effective the training is likely to be.

P2: Why do I need to read all the different stories if I’m only worried about one thing?

P1: Actually, we will ask you about your personal stressors, and give you more tailored stories. However, we also want you to learn how to apply flexible thinking to lots of stressful situations so that you can then apply that skill to the broad range of stressful situations that might come up for you.

P2: Why are there some negative endings to the stories?

P1: The goal of showing different types of stories and endings is to teach you how to think flexibly, and consider multiple outcomes. We know that things don't end positively 100 percent of the time.

P1: What was it like to think in this new way? How would your life be different if you thought like this? Try it out -- our goal is to apply new ways of thinking in your daily life.
